statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

article.description:
Alonzo Mourning made a hook shot with 47.2 seconds left, and Eddie Jones scored 29 points to lead Miami to an
89-87 victory over the Indiana Pacers on Monday night.
article.headline: Jones scores 29 as Heat finally win one
article.linkText: Heat's six-game losing streak ends vs. Pacers
article.story:
INDIANAPOLIS (AP) -- The Miami Heat decided to do something about their mounting frustration.
Jones

Eddie Jones scored 29 points and Alonzo Mourning scored the game-winning basket with 47.2 seconds left to lead the Heat to an 89-87 victory over the Indiana Pacers on Monday night. Mourning, who finished with 19 points, made a hook shot over Jermaine O'Neal to snap the Heat's six-game losing streak. "We made a little more of an effort down the stretch. We made better decisions down the stretch," Mourning said. "It just boiled down to getting fed up. We know we have enough talent to win the majority of the games we've lost." Miami, which trailed by five points with less than 5 minutes remaining, used a 15-9 run to clinch its first victory since Dec. 15. The Pacers led 79-77 after Jalen Rose hit a baseline jumper with 2:40 remaining. Mourning then hit a 13-footer with 2:15 left, tying the score at 79. On the Heat's next possession, Mourning battled with O'Neal for possession and scored over O'Neal's outstretched arm. The Heat then sealed the win from the free-throw line. Rose and Reggie Miller hit 3-pointers for the Pacers in the final minute. Rod Strickland had 14 points and 10 rebounds, and Jim Jackson added 12 points and 10 rebounds for the Heat. "At the end of the game, we executed," Jackson said. "Hopefully, this will start something. This is the kind of way we should be playing. This is the true talent of this team." Miami coach Pat Riley said the Heat are trying to regain the respect they've lost in their worst start since he took over in 1995. "This is the first game that we fought for and made good plays," Riley said. "It's very encouraging. The only way to win is to have great players play well every night." The Heat took away Indiana's fast-breaking offense and reliance on Al Harrington and O'Neal, who missed his first seven shots. They each scored eight points and the Pacers were outscored in the paint. The two combined to shoot 3-for-9 in the fourth quarter and Indiana made just two of its last 11 shots. Jonathan Bender matched his career high with 20 points. Rose added 20 points and Miller 13 for the Pacers, who lost their second straight game. O'Neal gave the Pacers an 81-79 lead with 2 minutes left. Jones hit a driving layup to tie the score at 81. The Pacers led 46-36 at halftime, but Jackson, Jones and Strickland rallied the Heat. They keyed a 13-3 run at the start of the third quarter that tied the score at 49. Brian Grant made two free throws to give the Heat a 62-61 lead. The Pacers scored the final three points, including a free throw by Travis Best after a technical foul was called on Miami assistant Stu Van Gundy. Bender came off the bench to score 10 points in the third, helping the Pacers maintain the lead. "He was great tonight, but it wasn't enough," Pacers coach Isiah Thomas said. Thomas said the Heat did a good job of shutting down O'Neal and Harrington. "It was crazy out there," Harrington said. "I had a very tough time shooting the ball. That's the first time I've shot that bad in a very long time." Game notes
The Heat are tied with the Chicago Bulls for the worst record in the NBA at 6-23. ....The Pacers are 2½ games behind Central Division-leading Milwaukee. ... ...Harrington had a career-high seven steals, two short of the NBA season high. ... Jamaal Tinsley set the Pacers' rookie record for assists in a season. He broke Chuck Person's record of 295 set in 1986-87 and now has 302. ... The Heat failed to score 100 points for the 29th straight game. ... The Pacers' reserves outscored Miami's substitutes 39-7.
